integer: In mathematics, an integer is a whole number (not a fraction or decimal) that can be positive, negative, or zero. Examples include -3, 0, 5, and 100.
opposite: Two numbers that are the same distance from zero on a number line, but on opposite sides. Their sum is always zero.
positive number: A number greater than zero. On a number line, positive numbers are to the right of zero.
number line: A straight line used to represent numbers in order. It usually has zero in the middle, with positive numbers to the right and negative numbers to the left. Number lines help visualize operations and compare values.
negative number: A number less than zero. On a number line, negative numbers are to the left of zero.
absolute value: The distance a number is from zero on a number line, always expressed as a positive number or zero.
